nodes.text: Economists' empirical estimates and IAMs (notably DICE) substantially underestimate economic damages from climate change and therefore should not be used to assess climate risks or to guide policy

Economists' damage estimates misrepresent scientific literature on climate tipping points, treating tipping points as unlikely this century despite scientific evidence they could be triggered before 2100

A common methodological assumption in economic damage studies is that only economic activities directly exposed to weather (e.g., agriculture, tourism) are affected by climate change, excluding manufacturing and most services

Many economic studies use spatial cross-sectional correlations between current regional temperature and income as a proxy for temporal impacts of global warming, assuming spatial patterns map to future global changes
Integrated Assessment Models including DICE, FUND and PAGE are calibrated to the flawed empirical estimates and hence inherit their underestimation of damages

Expert elicitation and IPCC-cited estimates used by economists produced small median damages (e.g., ~2–4% GDP at 3°C), but responses showed extreme disagreement and scientists predicted much larger damages

Post-2014 empirical studies that abandon some flawed assumptions produce larger damage estimates but still often extrapolate historical temperature-GDP relationships forward and keep the assumption that only weather-exposed sectors matter
Scientific literature identifies multiple tipping elements (e.g., Arctic sea-ice, Greenland ice sheet, AMOC) that can be triggered this century and can cascade, amplifying damages

The assumption that indoor or non-weather-exposed sectors are insulated is false because climate impacts (wildfires, floods, extreme heat, supply-chain and input disruptions, biodiversity and energy impacts) affect factories, offices, inputs and workers and can make locations uninhabitable

Using current spatial temperature-income fits to predict future global warming damages is invalid because regional economies reflect historical adaptation, trade, soil and institutional configurations and because global warming can produce novel climates and extremes not represented in current spatial variation

DICE is based on a Ramsey growth model with saddle-path stability, exogenous TFP and full employment and assumes abatement is a net cost to the whole economy, which structurally limits its representation of collapse and of environmental input dependence

Mathematical property: the Ramsey/DICE framework enforces a unique saddle-path equilibrium with 'jump' adjustment in consumption, requiring assumptions that prevent endogenous economic collapse solutions

Sensitivity simulations of DICE with highly increased damage coefficients show extreme resilience: the model either fails numerically at very high damages or produces corner solutions (immediate full mitigation, very low consumption, then eventual recovery) rather than economic collapse
Because DICE cannot generate collapse regardless of damage severity, it underrepresents potential systemic economic catastrophes from climate tipping points and input losses

Therefore empirical economic damage estimates and IAMs calibrated to them (e.g., DICE, FUND, PAGE) should be rejected for assessing climate risk and for policy development; science-based approaches that include tipping points and environmental inputs should take precedence
